value: population=no indigenous inhabitants; Indonesian fishermen access lagoon and fresh water at Ashmore Reef's West Islet

are a territory off the northwest coast of

.

These uninhabited islands came under Australian authority in 1931; formal administration began two years later. Ashmore Reef supports a rich and diverse avian and marine habitat; in 1983 it became a National Nature Reserve. Cartier Island, a former bombing range, is now a marine reserve.

This location is not a suitable tourist destination due to restrictions on access and being in the area of illegal boat movements.

Understanding its location is a useful reference point for understanding boats and their passage between Indonesia and Australia.  Monitoring of, or patrolling of the location is, in all probability, a part of the Australian government's policies of controlling illegal immigration.

value: Image:Ashmore and Cartier Islands-CIA WFB Map.png

As the islands are administered by

, the official language might be English depending on the actual presence of Australian officials.
Indonesian fisherman have used the islands, but it is highly likely they would be more fluent in their mother tongue - likely Rotinese or other eastern Indonesian languages - than in Indonesian.
It is a protected area. A permit from the Australian government is needed for civilians to set foot on the islands.
There are no facilities on the islands
Noting status of water supply, and low lying nature of the islands, best to keep away.
The wells that may be available have cholera present.
If due to an accident you find yourself in the area of these islands and their reefs - the Indonesian island of Roti is 144 km north, and Australia's north west coast is over 300 km to the south.
